title: 203.1C — Using BS 7671 on a Job

A quick-reference guide with simplified tables and common installation guidance within set limits.
A widely accepted technical standard used as evidence of safe practice and competence.
A deliberate choice not to follow a specific BS 7671 requirement, which must be justified and recorded as safe.
Showing you took all reasonable steps to prevent danger by following recognised safe methods and recording your decisions.

content.title: BS 7671: The Bridge Between Law and Practice
content.content:
In the UK, the Electricity at Work Regulations (EAWR) is the law (statutory). EAWR is written in broad terms: you must prevent danger. It does not tell you the exact technical rules for every installation decision.

BS 7671 (the IET Wiring Regulations) is non-statutory (not a law), but it is the recognised technical standard for electrical installations. In practice, applying BS 7671 correctly is widely accepted as strong evidence that you have taken reasonable precautions and worked safely.

For a real job, BS 7671 provides the technical rules for things like:
- Protection against electric shock (e.g., disconnection times and additional protection)
- Selection of equipment (e.g., choosing suitable protective devices and cables)
- Installation methods (e.g., support, mechanical protection, and routing)

Key idea:
- EAWR tells you your legal duty (prevent danger)
- BS 7671 tells you a recognised technical way to meet that duty

So, BS 7671 protects the user by improving safety, and it protects the electrician by providing a clear, defendable technical basis for decisions.

questions.questionText: Is BS 7671 a statutory or non-statutory document?
questions.hint: Is it a law passed by Parliament, or a technical standard used as guidance/evidence?

questions.questionText: Which statutory regulation does BS 7671 help electricians comply with in practice?
questions.hint: It is the main electrical safety law for work activities.

questions.questionText: In one sentence, what is the main workplace purpose of using BS 7671?
questions.expectedAnswer: To follow a recognised technical standard for safe installations and provide evidence of safe practice.
questions.hint: Think: safety + evidence (how you prove you worked properly).

questions.questionText: How do EAWR (the law) and BS 7671 (the recognised standard) work together to protect an electrician legally?
questions.expectedAnswer: EAWR sets the legal duty to prevent danger, and BS 7671 provides recognised technical rules that help show you met that duty with reasonable precautions and safe practice.
questions.hint: One says what your legal duty is; the other shows a safe, defendable way to meet it.

content.title: Navigating the Book: Parts, Chapters, Sections, and Regulations
content.content:
BS 7671 is large, but it is organised so you can find what you need quickly. Think of it as going from big topics to small rules:

1) Parts (big categories)
2) Chapters and Sections (narrow the topic)
3) Regulation numbers (the exact requirement)

You do not need to memorise lots of numbers. You need a repeatable lookup workflow:
- Start with the Contents if you know the topic area
- Use the Index if you only have keywords (e.g., RCD, socket-outlet, identification, bonding)
- Find the relevant regulation(s)
- Read the requirement carefully (including any conditions/exceptions)
- Apply it to the job
- Record what you did and what you referenced

Citing a regulation number on a job sheet or certificate is a professional habit. It shows your decision came from a recognised standard, not guesswork.

Example site note format:
- Decision: 30 mA RCD additional protection provided to socket-outlets.
- Evidence: BS 7671 Reg 411.3.3 cited in job notes.

(You will not be judged on memorising 411.3.3. You will be judged on using a workflow that finds the right requirement and recording it.)

questions.questionText: Name the main structural layers used to navigate BS 7671 from largest to smallest.
questions.hint: Start big (Parts) and end with the exact rule (Regulation number).

questions.questionText: What is the Index used for when working with BS 7671?
questions.expectedAnswer: To find topics using keywords and locate relevant regulation areas quickly.
questions.hint: It is at the back and is alphabetical.

questions.questionText: What does citing a regulation number in your notes actually do?
questions.expectedAnswer: It links your decision to a specific requirement in the recognised standard.
questions.hint: It shows the decision is based on the rules, not a personal opinion.

questions.questionText: Why is citing a regulation number considered part of proving due diligence?
questions.expectedAnswer: Because it shows you consulted a recognised standard and made an informed decision based on a specific requirement, which helps demonstrate reasonable precautions and safe practice.
questions.hint: Think: evidence that you checked the rules properly.

content.title: Choosing the Right Tool: BS 7671 vs OSG vs Guidance Notes
content.content:
Professional electricians use a suite of guidance documents. The skill is choosing the right one quickly and correctly:

1) On-Site Guide (OSG)
- Best for quick checks on common installations (typically domestic/small commercial) within its limits.
- Fast tables and standard arrangements.
- If the job is unusual, high-risk, outside the normal limits, or not covered clearly: move to BS 7671.

2) BS 7671
- The master technical standard.
- Use this when the job is complex, outside OSG scope, or you need the exact requirement.

3) Guidance Notes
- Deeper explanation and practical interpretation.
- Use these when you need help applying the requirement or understanding the correct method (e.g., test methods in GN3, special installations/locations support depending on the topic).

Fast workflow (what good electricians actually do):
- Start with OSG for a standard job.
- If anything is non-standard: confirm in BS 7671.
- If the rule is unclear in practice: use Guidance Notes to interpret and apply correctly.

Rule of thumb:
- OSG = quickest check (when the job is standard)
- BS 7671 = authoritative requirement (when you must be exact)
- Guidance Notes = practical interpretation (when you need method and meaning)

questions.questionText: Which document is designed for quick, everyday reference on-site for common installs?
questions.hint: It is the quick-reference book.

questions.questionText: Which document contains the master set of technical requirements?
questions.hint: This is the main technical standard book.

questions.questionText: Which document is best when you need deeper explanation of how to apply a requirement in practice?
questions.hint: These are the interpretation books.

questions.questionText: You are installing a standard domestic socket circuit. Which book do you check first, and what makes you switch to BS 7671?
questions.expectedAnswer: Check the OSG first for the standard tables and limits. Switch to BS 7671 if the situation is unusual, outside OSG scope, high-risk, or not clearly covered by the OSG.
questions.hint: Start fast for standard jobs, then go authoritative when the job is non-standard.

content.title: Worked Example: A Repeatable Lookup Workflow (Socket RCD Check)
content.given: You need to check whether a new socket-outlet in a domestic garage requires additional protection by a 30 mA RCD, and you want to record evidence of your decision.

steps.result: Do socket-outlets in this situation require 30 mA RCD additional protection?
Start with the OSG because this is a common domestic scenario.
Use the Index/Contents under keywords like socket-outlets and RCD.

steps.description: Confirm the authoritative requirement and any conditions.
steps.result: If the job is straightforward and within OSG guidance, proceed. If any doubt, confirm in BS 7671 and read the exact requirement wording and conditions.

steps.description: Extract the requirement and cite the regulation number (example).
steps.result: Example outcome: Provide additional protection by 30 mA RCD for relevant socket-outlets. Cite the appropriate regulation number (commonly referenced as Reg 411.3.3 for additional protection of socket-outlets, depending on circumstances and current edition).

steps.description: Record a minimum-quality site note to prove due diligence.
steps.result: Site note template: Decision + document + regulation(s) + brief reason. Example: Additional protection by 30 mA RCD provided to garage socket-outlet; checked against BS 7671 Reg 411.3.3; recorded for compliance evidence.

content.notes: The key skill is not memorising numbers. The key skill is using a repeatable workflow to find the right requirement and recording the evidence clearly.

content.title: Guided Practice: Evidence Notes (Identification / Sleeving)
content.problem: You are wiring a one-way lighting circuit. You need to identify the switched live correctly and make sure conductors are identified properly (e.g., sleeving/marking). You must check the requirements and record what you followed.

steps.prompt: For a quick standard check, which document would you look at first?
steps.hint: Use the quick-reference guide first for common installs.

steps.prompt: If you need the exact requirement wording and the official rule, which document must you use?
steps.hint: Use the master technical standard for exact rules.

steps.prompt: What two pieces of evidence must your job notes include to prove you checked the rules?
Write a one-line site note using the template: Decision + document + regulation(s) + reason (short).
steps.expectedAnswer: Example: Switched live identified and sleeved as required; checked against BS 7671 (cite relevant reg number); recorded to show due diligence.
steps.hint: It does not need perfect wording. It must include decision + document + reg number + short reason.

content.title: What MUST Be Recorded (Due Diligence Standard)
content.content:
When you make a technical decision on a job, your notes should be good enough that another competent electrician can see what you did and why.

Minimum recording standard (use this every time):
1) Decision made (what you installed / selected / changed)
2) Document used (OSG / BS 7671 / Guidance Note)
3) Regulation number(s) (or the exact section reference if using OSG)
4) Reason it applies to THIS job (one short line)

If you deviate from BS 7671, your record must be stronger:
- What you did differently (the deviation)
- Why you deviated (reason)
- How you still achieved equal or better safety (technical justification)
- Who approved/authorised it (if applicable)
- Where it is recorded (certificate / design note / job sheet)

This is what turns guidance into evidence.

content.title: Your Turn: Document Choice + Recording Drills

questions.questionText: You need the official wording of a requirement for a complex industrial site. Which document do you use?
questions.hint: Complex/industrial jobs usually go beyond quick-guide limits.

questions.questionText: You understand the rule but you are unsure how to apply it in practice (method/interpretation). Which document helps most?
questions.hint: These explain how and why, not just what.

questions.questionText: Write a short site note that proves due diligence for a socket circuit decision (include: decision + document + regulation number + reason).
expectedAnswer: Additional protection by 30 mA RCD provided to socket-outlets; checked in BS 7671 Reg 411.3.3; recorded to show compliance evidence.
Installed 30 mA RCD additional protection; referenced BS 7671 Reg 411.3.3; noted for due diligence.
questions.hint: Use the template: Decision + document + regulation(s) + reason (short).

questions.questionText: How does using the OSG for a quick check, then confirming in BS 7671 and recording a regulation number, help you meet your statutory duties under EAWR?
questions.expectedAnswer: The OSG helps you apply common safe standards quickly, and BS 7671 provides the authoritative technical requirement. Recording the regulation number and decision creates evidence of due diligence that you took reasonable precautions to prevent danger under EAWR.
questions.hint: Connect: quick check → authoritative requirement → written evidence for the law.

questions.questionText: You are installing a circuit in a higher-risk environment. Explain the full process: which document(s) you start with, how you find the requirement, what you record, and why this protects both the user and you legally. (3–4 sentences)
questions.expectedAnswer: Start with BS 7671 for the authoritative requirements and use the Index/Contents to locate the relevant topic and regulation numbers. Use Guidance Notes if you need practical interpretation of how to apply the requirement safely in that environment. Record the decision, the document(s) used, the regulation number(s), and a short reason showing why it applies to the job. This protects the user by ensuring the installation meets recognised safety rules and protects the electrician legally by demonstrating due diligence under EAWR.
questions.hint: Mention: documents → lookup → cite regs → record decision + reason → safety + legal evidence.

content.title: Spaced Review

questions.questionText: Define a statutory document in one sentence.
questions.expectedAnswer: A statutory document is a law passed by Parliament that must be followed.
questions.hint: Think: legal requirement.

questions.questionText: Define a non-statutory document in one sentence.
questions.expectedAnswer: A non-statutory document is guidance or a recognised technical standard that is not law but can be used as evidence of safe practice.
questions.hint: Think: guidance/evidence, not legislation.

questions.questionText: What does EAWR stand for?
questions.hint: The key statutory law for electrical work activities.

questions.questionText: What does OSG stand for?
questions.hint: The quick-reference guide.
